page.title: 13Agriculture
page.content:
Farming has gradually changed in the Halling and Snodland area. In Roman times there may have been vineyards in Holborough and Halling.Hops later became an important crop.
More recently fields have been used for crops such as barley, peas, rape- seed, and potatoes.
Near the river, the marshlands are used to graze small herds of cattle. The grassland is rich and green. Some grass is cut for hay.
There has been woodcutting in and around Halling for many hundreds of years. At first the wood was used for fuel and then for hop poles.Chestnut woods are still harvested.In Upper Halling there is a wood-yard specialising in fencing.
